I had a hard time understanding how exactly HyperNEAT works,
so , here i su=
mmarized all the ideas, hoping someone could clear my doubts:

So far i und=
erstood that:

- HyperNEAT uses 2 types of networks: CPPNs and Perceptron-t=
ype, CPPNs are evolved, perceptron-type are not because depend directly on =
CPPN weights
- A CPPN outputs weights only and it doesn't connect inputs or=
 outpus of the problem domain, so, no real data passes through CPPN
- Weigh=
ts produced by a CPPN are used to build perceptron type neural networks whi=
ch are connected to input/outputs of the problem domain.
- There are 2 type=
 of activation functions, for each network type
  1. Activation function of=
 the CPPN, which can be of any type, and it can output any floating point v=
alue
  2. Activation function of the perceptron-type network in form of (1/=
(1+(exp(-(slope*activesum))))) which output values are in range from 0 to 1=

- There is no evolution mechanism for the topology of perceptron-type netw=
orks wich is fixed from the begining,  The only evolution that takes place =
is evolution of the CPPN, wich is based on the coordinates of the source an=
d destination node to produce the weight
- The perceptron-type networks hav=
e only 2 layers (input & output) and it is not possible to have hidden laye=
rs, because CPPN can not produce them by definition, so all the hidden laye=
rs must be engineered by hand of the designer. 
  For example, in order to =
have one hidden layer in HyperNEAT for a particular problem, 2 perceptron-t=
ype networks (which will be produced by 2 separated CPPNs)  must be joined =
together, the outputs of the first perceptron-type network (produced by the=
 first CPPN) must be connected with the input of the second perceptron-type=
 network (produced by the second CPPN). 


Is this how HyperNEAT works?


T=
hanks in advance
